awd_abstract_narration: A series of Molecular Dynamics simulations on atomic arrays of                  several different materials of up to one million atoms in order to              determine critical dislocation mobility parameters is proposed.                 These are the Peierls stress (the stress required to initiate                   dislocation motion), and the temperature dependent damping                      coefficient (obtained from the dislocation velocity as a function of            applied stress and temperature).  These quantities are extremely                difficult to measure directly, or estimate by theoretical means, yet            they are of considerable importance in predicting and understanding             the plastic response and fracture behavior of materials.  Computer              simulation are ideally suited, now that reliable interatomic                    interactions can be constructed for selected metal systems by means             of the Embedded Atom Method.  This program would be the first serious           attempt to determine these quantities for specific metals by computer           simulation methods.//
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
